Especially in complex lung segment surgery, it is more controversial. Preoperative three-dimensional reconstruction (3DR) is one of the effective methods to ensure the smooth operation, but its role in complex segmentectomy has not yet been verified. This article aims to evaluate the value of preoperative three-dimensional reconstruction in complex pulmonary segmentectomy by retrospective analysis of preoperative three-dimensional reconstruction assisted single-port video-assisted thoracoscopic complex pulmonary segmentectomy and comparison of surgical related indicators. Methods The clinical data of patients with lung cancers who underwent single-port thoracoscopic complex segmentectomy ( n Results There were 125 patients in each group after PSM, and the baseline characteristics of patients were comparable. There were no significant differences in age, sex, BMI, smoking history, tumor histology and tumor size between the two groups (all P P Conclusion This is the first study to evaluate the usefulness of preoperative 3D reconstruction in complex segmentectomy. The results showed that the use of preoperative three-dimensional reconstruction for complex pulmonary segmentectomy was a safe and effective method, which could significantly reduce the operation time and blood loss. Therefore, it is particularly important to understand the anatomical characteristics of the patients around the lesions and the planning of the operation before the operation. Although many experienced doctors can have a general understanding of the structure of segmental bronchi by reading CT images, there are great limitations in understanding the target segment of blood vessels, because the shape of blood vessels is not as regular as that of bronchi, and they are prone to variation. Artificial intelligence three-dimensional reconstruction (3DR) system is favored by many doctors because it can display the anatomical structure of pulmonary segmental hilum stereoscopically and intuitively, and accurately identify the potential variation and tumor location, especially in complex pulmonary segmental resection. A different imaging interpretation and analysis system (IQQA-3D; developed by IQQA-Chest, EDDA Technology, Princeton Junction, New Jersey, USA) was first applied and reported in China by our unit, which can perform three-dimensional reconstruction of lung trachea and pulmonary vessels with satisfactory results [ 8 The objective of this single-center, retrospective study was to assess the value of 3D reconstruction in complex segmentectomy by comparing the operation-related indicators and short-term survival outcomes with and without preoperative 3D reconstruction by propensity score-matching (PSM) analysis. Patients and methods Study population This study retrospectively analyzed the clinical data of 299 patients with single or multiple lung cancers admitted to Union Hospital Affiliated to Fujian Medical University from August 2015 to February 2019. The Institutional Review Board of our hospital approved the study. All enrolled patients had pathologically confirmed primary lung cancer (including pre-invasive lesions AAH/CIS). The term ‘pulmonary nodule’ has been replaced with ‘lung cancer’ throughout. All patients underwent single-port video-assisted thoracoscopic complex segmentectomy. The decision to perform preoperative 3DR was at the surgeon’s discretion, primarily based on: (1) Nodule location near segmental borders; (2) Suspected vascular anomalies on CT; (3) Planned combined subsegmentectomy. We divided the patients into two groups according to whether they had 3D reconstruction before operation: reconstruction group (3DR) and non-reconstruction group (non-3DR). Indications for segmentectomy include: (1) inability to tolerate lobectomy due to poor pulmonary function or other severe comorbidities; (2) at least one of the following 3 conditions in patients with lung cancers ≤ 2 cm: ① AIS on pathology; ② GGO ratio ≥ 50% on CT imaging; and ③ doubling time ≥ 400 days on radiological monitoring [ 9 Inclusion criteria included (I) performing a single type of complex segmental surgery regardless of the number of lung cancers. (II) All procedures (lung segment, subsegment, combined lung segment or subsegment, lung segment + subsegment) were performed under single-port thoracoscopy. (III) meet the indications for segmental resection of the lung. Exclusion criteria included (I) patients with extensive pleural adhesions. (II) simple segmentectomy. (III) simultaneous lobectomy or segmental lobectomy. (IV) Non-single-port thoracoscopic surgery (such as conventional thoracoscopy, Da Vinci robot, etc.). (V) Patients with right middle lung nodules. (VI) incomplete data. When the patient’s informed consent was obtained, we performed an anatomical segmentectomy. We retrospectively analyzed all 299 patients who underwent single-port video-assisted thoracoscopic complex segmentectomy to compare the impact of preoperative three-dimensional reconstruction on perioperative outcomes. Ethics approval This study was conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki. The Institutional Review Board (IRB) of Union Hospital Affiliated to Fujian Medical University approved this study (Approval No: 2020WSJK072). Written informed consent was obtained from all individual participants after detailed explanation of surgical procedures and data usage. Preoperative evaluation All patients underwent preoperative enhanced thin-slice CT scan (slice thickness 0.625 mm), as well as necessary cardiopulmonary function tests. If the surgeon deems it necessary, he will consider the whole body examination such as bone scan, head magnetic resonance, whole abdomen ultrasound and supraclavicular lymph ultrasound. Refer to the eighth edition of UICC/AJCC for tumor type, lymph node and metastasis staging of malignant tumors [ 10 Surgical technique: In our institution, anatomical segmentectomy was performed using the single-port thoracoscopic technique we have previously reported [ 8 11 12 12 Patients in the three-dimention reconstruction group (3DR) need to import the enhanced thin-layer CT scan image data into the three-dimensional reconstruction system before operation, locate the lung cancers through the reconstruction system, and generate the three-dimensional structure of the bronchus, artery and vein of the target pulmonary segment to obtain the precise anatomical structure of the target pulmonary segment; According to the anatomical characteristics of different individuals, on the premise of ensuring the resection margin of the tumor, the target lung segment to be resected was determined, and the surgical path, surgical resection process and resection range were planned. After surgical resection, the surgeon needs to confirm the complete resection of the tumor by naked eye, ensure adequate resection margin, and confirm the negative resection of lung segments and subsegmental bronchi and lymph nodes by intraoperative frozen examination. When the surgical margin is insufficient, further resection of the adjacent (sub-) pulmonary segments is required. We included only patients with complete resection confirmed by intraoperative and postoperative pathology who underwent complex segmentectomy only. Because we intended to evaluate the effect of preoperative 3D reconstruction on the short-term surgical outcome of complex segmentectomy, we excluded patients who required additional lobectomy due to upregulation of pathologic stage or malignant histologic causes. Follow-up evaluation Perioperative data were collected from hospital medical records, anesthesia and operating room records, and electronic medical records for each patient. Perioperative mortality was defined as death within 30 days after surgery. All patients were followed up every 3–6 months from the day of surgery until death or the last follow-up. Final follow-up data were collected through December 2023. IQR = interquartile range In the postoperative analysis, there were no perioperative deaths in either group, and the postoperative hospital stay between the two groups was 4.4 ± 1.6 days vs. 4.9 ± 2.9d, P P P P P 3 Discussion While the diagnostic rate of early lung cancer continues to improve, the effectiveness of anatomical segmentectomy for patients with small peripheral NSCLC has been fully demonstrated [ 14 16 17 Compared with traditional lobectomy, the biggest advantage of segmentectomy is that through our selection of cases, the appropriate patients can be completely resected while preserving normal lung tissue and lung function to the maximum extent, so segmentectomy is of great significance for patients with poor lung function and multiple lung cancers. Previous multicenter and prospective studies have shown that when the distance from the tumor to the resection margin is greater than the tumor diameter, no malignant positive margin is found [ 18 Pulmonary segmental surgery is similar to lobectomy, which requires segmental bronchus and the root of segmental artery and vein to be cut off, but the position of segmental door is often deep in the lung parenchyma, and the operation process is like “digging the lung”, which increases the difficulty of quickly and correctly identifying the structure of pulmonary segment during the operation, and then leads to prolonged operation time and increased complications; In addition, complex pulmonary segmentectomy is more difficult because of the more complex segmental structure and intersegmental plane, as well as the tricky operation angle. In order to effectively solve the problems associated with pulmonary segmentectomy and ensure the smooth implementation of the operation, our unit introduced a three-dimensional reconstruction system to assist single-port thoracoscopic pulmonary segmentectomy, and generated three-dimensional anatomical images of the bronchi, arteries and veins of the target lung through preoperative three-dimensional reconstruction, which provided more accurate positioning of lung cancers before operation. It can determine the distribution and shape of bronchi and arteries and veins around the lesion in advance, and then plan the scope and process of surgical resection to ensure the safe, effective and rapid implementation of the operation [ 11 Our analysis compared the surgical and surgical outcomes of complex segmentectomies with and without preoperative 3D reconstruction. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first analysis to date of the effects of a 3D reconstruction system alone on complex segmentectomies. The results of our study demonstrate that in single-port thoracoscopic complex segmentectomy, the operation time was shorter and the blood loss was less in the three-dimensional reconstruction group than in the non-reconstruction group, and the difference was statistically significant. It is considered that this is because after three-dimensional reconstruction, we have enough prediction and planning for the anatomical structure of the segment door before operation, and have a full understanding and preparation for the potential anatomical variations. During the operation, we only need to fully dissociate the target blood vessels and bronchi, which greatly reduces the identification of the surrounding non-target blood vessels and bronchi, shortens the operation time and reduces the wound bleeding. In the non-reconstruction group, the operation time was prolonged and the wound bleeding was increased due to the large range of anatomic segmental portal structure caused by the identification of anatomic variations, the inadequate resection margin caused by the misestimation of the lesion location in the lung segment to be resected, and the “wedge resection” had to be added to the original resection margin of the lung segment to ensure the resection margin. Notably, the spatial understanding gained through 3DR appeared transferable to non-3DR cases. Surgeons reported improved ability to mentally reconstruct complex anatomy based on conventional CT images after repeated 3DR exposure, suggesting a persistent learning effect beyond specific 3DR-guided procedures. Under the guidance of preoperative three-dimensional reconstruction results, we can better understand the anatomical structure of the target lung segment before and during the operation, and reduce the difficulty of learning thoracoscopy-assisted lung segmentectomy, which is of great significance to young doctors; Especially for lung cancers at the junction of pulmonary segments, as shown in Fig. 1 In addition, in the statistics of the hospitalization costs of the two groups of patients, the hospitalization costs of the 3DR group were lower than those of the non-3DR group before and after PSM, which was considered to be due to the fact that the 3DR group reduced the use of titanium clips and other materials due to the accurate identification of anatomical structures during the operation. And that incidence rate of complication such as air leakage and the like is reduced and the hospitalization cost is further reduce due to the fact that the door structure of a large-range anatomical section is avoided. In this retrospective study, there was no statistical difference between the reconstruction group and the non-reconstruction group in terms of mortality, complication rate, hospital stay, drainage time, drainage volume, and hospital costs. The number of dissected lymph nodes in the non-reconstruction group was slightly more than that in the reconstruction group, but there was no statistical significance. It was considered that the number of dissected lymph nodes in the non-reconstruction group was more than that in the reconstruction group because more anatomical exposure of hilar and segmental structures was needed. This also illustrates the advantages of three-dimensional reconstruction in simplifying surgery. Regarding surgical training, artificial simulation labs using 3DR technology offer significant advantages: (1) Risk-free rehearsal of complex anatomic variations; (2) Standardized assessment of surgical planning skills. However, limitations include high setup costs and potential discrepancies between virtual and intraoperative anatomy. Future studies should evaluate whether such simulation translates to improved operative outcomes.” This study has several limitations. First, because of its retrospective and single-institution nature, and second, because the patients in the reconstruction group were not randomly selected, there was a selection bias between the two groups, which could not be ruled out by PSM. Thirdly, because our sample size is relatively small, the confidence interval is large, and there is a large likelihood of positive or negative effects, we hope that this problem can be solved by accumulating more data through multi-center studies in the future. In conclusion, our study shows that the use of preoperative 3D reconstruction system for reconstruction and planning is a safe and effective way for patients requiring complex pulmonary segmentectomy, which can significantly reduce the operation time and blood loss, and is worthy of recommendation. However, the long-term effect of complex segmental resection assisted by preoperative three-dimensional reconstruction in the treatment of non-small cell lung cancer remains to be further studied.
